meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> lets you <kanji>add</kanji> words together to form a sentence. Marvel at the mighty additive power your mouth holds! You add words together in an amazing fashion!
reading_mnemonic: Your parents are so proud of you being able to <kanji>add</kanji> words together that they surprise you with a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Wow! You add some stickers to your bumper and add your favorite playlist to the car radio. Let's drive.

meaning_mnemonic:
On the bottom of <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>root</radical>s, there’s a <radical>stamp</radical> that tells you the <kanji>season</kanji> in which it was cut.

Additionally, the stamp also has information on the condition of the bamboo’s <kanji>joint</kanji>s, because no one wants to buy bamboo with damaged joints!
reading_mnemonic: These <kanji>season</kanji> stamps are marked on bamboo <reading>sets</reading> (せつ). You can't buy a single banana or a single grape, and just like that, if you want some nice seasonal bamboo, you have to buy them in sets.

meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>tsunami</radical> coming, but the escape <radical>slide</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>drunkard</radical> and <radical>creeper</radical>, and you can see your chances of escaping <kanji>decrease</kanji> rapidly.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>decrease</kanji> in the chances of escaping the tsunami is really upsetting <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), who's waiting impatiently behind you.

meaning_mnemonic: When they migrate to a <radical>river</radical>, a group of <radical>geoducks</radical> must do so in a certain <kanji>order</kanji> and <kanji>sequence</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, they go in birth-month <kanji>order</kanji>, starting from <reading>June</reading> (じゅん). No one knows why they follow this June-based <kanji>sequence</kanji>. But the geoducks born in June always go first in the migration order.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>valley</radical> it will change its <kanji>form</kanji>. Its <kanji>appearance</kanji> will alter completely!
reading_mnemonic: Its new <kanji>appearance</kanji> looks familiar to you, like it's a big <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう) cup! A valley with a roof on it looks exactly like a yogurt cup. Huh!

meaning_mnemonic: To a <radical>narwhal</radical>, a <radical>towel</radical> is just normal <kanji>cloth</kanji>. They're always wet so towel cloth is all they know.
reading_mnemonic: If you use this type of <kanji>cloth</kanji> for your clothes and blankets people will call you a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). They think you're a fool who can't tell the difference between human cloth and towel cloth.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>easy</radical> radical and the <kanji>easy</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: What would be an <kanji>easy</kanji> reading for this kanji? <reading>い</reading>! The sound easy starts with!

meaning_mnemonic: Give some <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>talent</radical>ed person and they'll have no problem accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji>. People with talent can make money out of pretty much anything, so shellfish are like easy-mode.
reading_mnemonic: This talented person really starts accumulating <kanji>wealth</kanji> when their <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) is unveiled. It's a half-man, half-shellfish cyborg that plays the <reading>xy</reading>lophone  (ざい), and everyone wants to buy it.

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> on your <radical>right</radical> to show that you're still <kanji>young</kanji>. Your body still works, you're happy, you have your entire life ahead of you! And everything smells like flowers.
reading_mnemonic: When <kanji>young</kanji> people look to the right, they'll see their future: a <reading>walke</reading>r (わか). You know, those metal contraptions with tennis balls on the bottoms to make sure they don't scrape the floor. Everything may be flowers and happiness now, but your future is in a walker.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to the <radical>director</radical> is judged immediately. You're having trouble understanding this <kanji>part of speech</kanji>, so he's trying to help you. But you say it over and over and he keeps saying you're wrong.
reading_mnemonic: The director asks you again, "What is the part of speech for the word <reading>shee</reading>p (し)?"

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>compare</radical>d to an <kanji>insect</kanji>, you’ll see that they're both shiny, but that the sun is much shinier than the insect.
reading_mnemonic: While you’re holding up an <kanji>insect</kanji> to the sun for comparison, a flock of <reading>con</reading>dors (こん) flies by, blocking out the sun. There are so many condors that they manage to totally block out the sun.

meaning_mnemonic: Passed out in front of your <radical>gate</radical> lies a former <radical>leader</radical>. He's now a <radical>drunkard</radical>, but once ran a popular <kanji>clique</kanji> called the Cool Kids <kanji>Clan</kanji>. The clan has fallen apart, and he no longer has a clique to call his own.
reading_mnemonic: Eventually you get sick and tired of this washed up <kanji>clan</kanji> leader and you gather your own <kanji>clique</kanji> to chase this guy away from your gate and your property. You and your friends grab some <reading>bats</reading> (ばつ) and use these bats to beat the drunkard leader. Being beaten with bats frightens him, and he scurries away.

meaning_mnemonic: At the edge of the <radical>cliff</radical>, two <radical>tree</radical>s mark the spot where you must <radical>stop</radical>, since any <kanji>continuation</kanji> requires a way across. The trees seem long enough to reach to the other side, but how are you going to chop them down?
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Continuation</kanji> is impossible unless you chop these trees down to make a bridge to the other side. You decide to use a <reading>wrecki</reading>ng (れき) ball. Luckily, there's one right by you. So you take the wrecking ball and knock the trees over, making a bridge with them.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tongue</radical> radical and the <kanji>tongue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Yee-haw!
reading_mnemonic: You’re sound asleep in bed when your <kanji>tongue</kanji> drops out of your mouth and you start to drool, getting saliva all over the bed <reading>sheet</reading> (した). You wake up with a soggy patch of sheet near your mouth and wipe the drool off your face. Your significant other sees the whole thing.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>bookshelf</radical> as a <kanji>book counter</kanji>. Duh. What, are you gonna count them one by one? Okay, well maybe, but you should count them while they're nice and organized on the shelves. Otherwise counting is going to be a huge pain.
reading_mnemonic: You use this <kanji>book counter</kanji> method to count all the books <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) has in her house. Remember her? She's got, like, a ton of books, but she's just a little girl so she needs some help. That's where your book counter know-how comes in handy.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>roof</radical> to keep yourself <radical>dry</radical> and safe from <kanji>outer space</kanji>. Look outside, above your roof, and you'll see outer space stretching above you.
reading_mnemonic: Why isn't it dry in <kanji>outer space</kanji>, you ask? Because of all the <reading>u</reading>ni (う) swimming around up there. They have nasty, wet, pointy spikes and they're all over the place.

meaning_mnemonic: You jumped off your <radical>roof</radical> for some <radical>reason</radical> and now you're floating in <kanji>midair</kanji>! You kick your legs a bit and move your arms like you're in water, but you're still just stuck there in midair.
reading_mnemonic: As you spin a bit in <kanji>midair</kanji> you look up and see <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (ちゅう) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam.

meaning_mnemonic: You'll work your <radical>soul</radical> to <radical>death</radical> if you're too <kanji>busy</kanji>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
reading_mnemonic: Take time out of your <kanji>busy</kanji> life and go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flag</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s in a <radical>black hole</radical>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <kanji>footwear</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You grab your <kanji>footwear</kanji> from the black hole. In your footwear (thanks to the shelter they provided), some <reading>ree</reading>ds (り) have grown in!

meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of this <kanji>group</kanji>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>group</kanji> is so big it takes you till <reading>dawn</reading> (だん) to get your measurement: they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (とん) too!

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
reading_mnemonic: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of <kanji>violence</kanji>. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.

meaning_mnemonic: A raging <radical>tsunami</radical> rises next to the calm <radical>sun</radical>. When you try to <radical>compare</radical> these two things, it's clear that they cannot <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
reading_mnemonic: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a <kanji>mix</kanji> — a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.

meaning_mnemonic: If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji> and cause <kanji>disorder</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
reading_mnemonic: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy Savage (らん). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A <kanji>riot</kanji> immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.

meaning_mnemonic: “Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
reading_mnemonic: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones <kanji>Junior</kanji> takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his <reading>to</reading>e (と) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
reading_mnemonic: You managed to <kanji>acquire</kanji> some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (とく) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."

meaning_mnemonic: It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
reading_mnemonic: Winter ends and, <kanji>renew</kanji>ed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: <reading>kay</reading>aking (かい)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to gather <radical>thread</radical> to <radical>sell</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> living. You want to make a living, don't you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>continue</kanji> to sell that thread because a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (ぞく) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> and your <radical>car</radical> is what you always <kanji>take along</kanji> with you. Make sure they're <kanji>connect</kanji>ed well so you don't lose them!
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> your scooter and your car. Anything else, you can do a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん) for!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in its <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to someone who's <kanji>morally good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto its head. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. Someone evil would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find someone <kanji>good</kanji> to reaffix them.
reading_mnemonic: Since you are <kanji>morally good</kanji>, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the <kanji>good</kanji> teachings of <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.

meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
reading_mnemonic: This isn't going well, so you pull out the weird kiss thread and <kanji>entangle</kanji> it around a <reading>rack</reading> (らく). Good thing that rack was there! Much better to have it entangled around a rack when you're trying to kiss someone.

meaning_mnemonic: Within the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove, someone asks your <radical>reason</radical> for being there, and you explain it's to harvest bamboo to craft a <kanji>flute</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a <kanji>flute</kanji>. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien <reading>tech</reading> (てき) in front of you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>History</kanji> was full of famous <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!

meaning_mnemonic: If you see some <radical>flowers</radical> that are <radical>dry</radical>, pull them up and you'll find a <kanji>potato</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Potato</kanji>es are totally <reading>emo</reading> (いも) because of the way they dry out flowers. Emo people and potatoes both like to dry out flowers.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> next to your <radical>village</radical> is where you <kanji>bury</kanji> the dead. People don't live forever, so every village has a patch of dirt specifically used for burying dead things.
reading_mnemonic: You don't just <kanji>bury</kanji> dead relatives here. You also buried your dead pet <reading>u</reading>ni (う) in that dirt. You thought having an uni as a pet would be a good idea. Too bad uni need water to survive.
